thread.title: Tokyo stocks close flat
thread.title_full: Tokyo stocks close flat | Business Spectator

author: AFP
title: Tokyo stocks close flat
text:
Tokyo's benchmark index has ended flat, pausing after a two-day rally, as investors kept to the sidelines ahead of a closely watched US jobs report.
The Nikkei 225 index at the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Friday ticked up 2.71 points to 17,725.13.
The broader Topix index of all first-section shares edged up 0.15 per cent, or 2.18 points, to 1,444.92.
Investors were awaiting US unemployment figures for September to be released later in the day as they look for fresh cues on US monetary policy.
Traders see an improving labour market as a key factor supporting the Federal Reserve's plan to hike near-zero interest rates.
"If the jobs number is strong, then an interest rate hike will look more likely, and if it's too weak, the market will think the US economy is weak," Soichiro Monji, chief strategist at Daiwa SB Investments, told Bloomberg News.
"Both good and bad numbers will negatively impact stocks. The best situation for the market would be to see no impact."
Spending among Japanese households rebounded in August, according to data published on Friday.
The upbeat figures were a rare bright spot in an otherwise gloomy string of trade, factory output and business confidence data that point to a contraction in the third quarter. Japan's July-September GDP figures are due next month.
In Tokyo share trading, car-maker Nissan advanced 1.52 per cent to Y1,167.5 on a solid monthly US sales report, beating market forecasts.
Supermarket giant Aeon climbed 2.11 per cent to Y1,959, while telecom firm SoftBank fell 0.07 per cent to Y5,625, recovering from a drop of more than one per cent by the lunch break.
Japan Tobacco rose 0.55 per cent to Y3,593, after the stock took a hammering in recent days as investors dismissed its $US5.0 billion ($A7.11 billion) purchase of a US-cigarette brand as too pricey.
On currency markets, the US dollar edged up to Y120.06 from Y119.93 on Thursday in New York.
